article.headline: Is this age discrimination? What older workers can do when theyâre marginalized at their job
article.body: This article is reprinted by permission from NextAvenue.org. About 10 years ago, my boss, mentor and close friend Angelina â who was then in her early 50s â lost her job at our well-known and respected Fortune 50 manufacturing company after working her way up to the executive suite. In the year before, I had noticed some subtle and troubling things about how she was being treated. I would attend a meeting and discover Angelina hadnât been invited. She was also asked to take on assignments well beneath her skill and talent level. Something didnât add up. When I asked the CEO about this, he said, âListen, Angelina has been in this business a long time. Maybe sheâs just tired, thatâs all.â Angelina was anything but tired. Thatâs when I knew two things for sure:Â tiredÂ is anÂ ageistÂ code word forÂ oldÂ and marginalizing someone is an effective way to get them to choose to leave, taking the employer off the hook. My neither tired nor old mentor opted to leave the company and went on to do great things elsewhere.Why marginalization at work is insidious and demoralizing Marginalization at work is a clear indicator of ageism. In fact, itâs the most insidious form. And itâs demoralizing. The original meaning of the verb âto marginalizeâ comes from editing. The editor would write notes off to the side of the document, usually in tiny and practically unreadable print. In todayâs workplace, when an older worker is marginalized, they too are often moved to the side in a position that feels unimportant. Like the notes in the manuscript, theyâre often made to feel tiny. When I wrote my book,Â âIâm Not Done: Itâs Time to Talk About Ageism in the Workplace,â I interviewed dozens of people in their 50s and 60s who had been pushed out or fired from their jobs. Not one of them had ever received a bad performance review. So, in addition to being upset, they were also mystified. You might want to read: Are you facing early retirement? Hereâs how to prepare As one man told me, âIt was almost like my seniority and experience was a negative to my boss, so he stopped including me in meetings about the agencyâs future strategy. But what he didnât know was that I had a coffee date almost every morning with young employees who wanted to pick my brain.â He was terminated during a ârestructuring.â Those young people are still calling him for advice.Marginalization and age discrimination I think most of us understand thatÂ age discriminationÂ is against the law, but we also need to understand that evidence of marginalization is often used to prove that the age discrimination existed. Itâs believed that a lot of companies use marginalization to get older workers to leave, allowing the companies to avoid paying severance. Related: Bye, boomer: the coming cull of workers over 50 Sue Ellen Eisenberg, an attorney with her own firm in Detroit, has taken on dozens of age discrimination cases and she knows marginalization is often a factor. âAll of sudden, once-valued employees feel less valued. They are forced into a role that no longer utilizes their strengths, they are literally and figuratively being muted and it can become a self-defeating cycle because the natural reaction is to doubt yourself,â says Eisenberg. Donât miss: As Trump and Biden trade age insults, older workers suffer In reality, she adds, ânothing has changed about your abilities as much as the organizationâs natural inclination to gravitate towards the next shiny thing. And once that starts to happen to someone, it can really wear them down, so this idea of leaving starts to sound like a plausible idea.â But even when marginalization doesnât lead to losing your job, it is hurtful and unpleasant.How marginalization can affect your health Whatâs more, marginalization has been proven to have damaging effects on emotional, mental and physical health. When people feel excluded at their workplace, they often describe feelings of anger, fear, depression, anxiety, sadness and stress. As a result, they become even more isolated from their colleagues. Not exactly a formula for top performance. Also see: Age discrimination is still a major obstacle for older workers This then can lead to a vicious cycle. When an employee is relegated to the margin, they simply will not be as well-informed so if they do get a chance to participate, their contribution might not be as sharp as in the past. Self-doubt creeps in and, unwittingly, the employee proves the employerâs âSuzy isnât as good as she used to beâ bias. That can then devolve into a performance review that could âjustifyâ Suzyâs termination.What to do if it happens to you So, what can you do if you think youâre being marginalized at work? Keep learning. Keep sharing your expertise and experience. Keep volunteering for new challenges. If you do those things and the marginalization continues, speak up to your boss or to HR or both.Â Keep notes of those conversations. Then, if nothing changes, consider calling an age discrimination attorney. Above all, donât let the marginalizing behavior erode your confidence.Â Remind yourself itâs not you, itâsÂ them. Wear your wisdom and experience like the badge of honor it is. Patti Temple Rocks, author ofÂ âIâm Not Done,â has held senior leadership positions in three sectors of the communications industry: PR, advertising and on the corporate side. She is passionate about fighting age discrimination and helping people understand how it harms individuals, businesses and society as a whole.
